text.text: A Guide to Tottenham

If you believe the rumours, Tottenham is in the process of irreversibly morphing into Dalston - something that seems to scare the shit out of locals eager to keep those community vibes strong and high-rise flats absent. 

This is a bustling multicultural blur of hustle: where some 200 languages fill the air; where industrial warehouses dominate the landscape; where venues still have a 4am licence (!). It's rough around the edges, but it's got hella heart - so come with us on our tour of Tottenaam.
Best for... escaping to South America

tip.text:
A little rough around the edges it might be, but the moment you step into Seven Sisters Indoor Market you're transported to a vibrant community market in Bogota, where South American locals meet to eat, drink, chat and chill at all times of day. In this shabby maze, various Spanish accents fill the air - it's an integral hub, and one of the best things about Seven Sisters.

In the various nooks there are over 100 Latin American traders offering services of all kinds: from hairdressers to South American supermarkets; internet cafes to beauty shops; and of course a couple of restaurants and cafes. Grab some of that sweet and delicious Colombian coffee or chomp down on a filling £1 empanada (or something else beige and tasty). Now here's hoping the developers don't get their way and turn this place into a 'pasta express'.

text.text: Stepping into Seven Sisters Market is straight up escapism: a trip to a vibrant community hub in Colombia, where South American locals meet to eat, drink, chat and chill at all times of day. In this shabby maze there are over 100 Latin American traders offering services of all kinds - we'd recommend grabbing some sweet, strong Colombian coffee and chomping down on a filling £1 beef empanada from Pueblito Paisa.
Best for... a cafe with some extras

tip.text:
It might take a little while to find amidst Tottenham’s warehouse district, but once you reach Craving Coffee you'll discover all you need for a relaxing sip, bite or chill. The light pours in from their south-facing windows, illuminating soft woods, white tiles and, most importantly, delicious coffee and healthy bites from a kitchen where food is not just an afterthought.

Coffee was their starting point, but now they’re up to all sorts - lunch and dinner here feature carefully constructed European dishes with high quality ingredients. The food has certainly gone to their head with supper clubs sitting alongside a bill of exhibitions and other cultural happenings from the Tottenham community. Yes sir, it's a local favourite.

text.text: Once you wipe the dust from your eyes - a hazard in this industrial patch - you'll stumble upon Craving Coffee: a calming cafe where sunlight pours in from the south-facing windows basking the white tiles, soft woods and greenery in a satisfying glow. The coffee is naturally top notch, but their kitchen also creates stuff to be sampled, and with supper clubs, events and exhibitions popping up, this has rapidly become a local hotspot.
Best for... pizza where you weren't expecting it

tip.text:
We're big into places that require a little discovering, and Loven feels like you've personally unearthed a gem. Amidst the carpet companies and biscuit factories, find the right street and press the right buzzer and you'll find yourself in a calming, chic space. Here light streams in and one big wood-burning oven dominates, creating the necessary heat for simple and delicious Neapolitan pizzas.

Set up by Fabrizio and Kate, Loven started out of a homemade oven in their back garden. Their late night pizza parties got popular - so popular that they're now deemed by those in the know to do the best pizza in Tottenham. Heavy on toppings and with over 20 varieties to choose from, these babies are also available as takeaway. With a bar to boot, this is an ideal place for a group eat - or even something a lil' romantic.

text.text: Find the right street and press the right buzzer and you'll land in the capable, flour-covered hands of Fabrizio - a chef who started whipping up his pizzas from his back yard. His famous pizza parties, created with his wife Kate, got so damn popular that they're now doing it in a chic space on the first floor of an office block. Those with the inside tip rate these as the best pizzas in Tottenham: simple Neapolitan pies that are heavy on toppings and heavier on flavour.
Best for... whatever you fancy

tip.text:
Every time we take a look at Tottenham, its star seems to be burning a 'lil brighter and nothing shows that more than Five Miles. This cavernous warehouse space is fitted with a bar, cafe, brewery, restaurant and club spot with nifty minimalist interiors complimented by friendly communal vibes and a very dope sound system. It's quickly become a destination worth traipsing up north for.

By tap, you're looking at twenty different brews including five from the on-site brewery, Affinity Brew Co. There are also negronis and espresso martinis, which sounds a surefire recipe for personal disaster. Meanwhile in the kitchen, Torshi are doing brunch and dinner with sharing menus featuring bits like fried chicken with pickled watermelon rind and zhoug and Yemeni falafel. Very tasty stuff.

What really makes this spot stand out, though, is the sound system and eclectic range of nights they put on within the 250 capacity spot. With a 4am licence and proximity to the Victoria line, this is just the type of late-night hub putting Tottenham on the map.

text.text: Five Miles is a jumping jack of all trades: a bar, cafe, brewery, restaurant and club spot all living inside a cavernous warehouse with minimalist interiors and a dope sound system. Depending on your mood, you can do a spot of remote working; tuck into some fried chicken; sip on an ale from their in-house brewery; and shake it until the early hours (4am) at one of their nice club nights. A destination, baby.
Best for... a cheap eat gem

tip.text:
Inside Bernie Grants Art Centre lies a colourful community hub that goes by the name of Blooming Scent, where locals from all walks of life sip on coffee, take a beer or tuck into some delicious Caribbean cooking. Owner of the cafe, Gina, has previously won the Pride of Britain award for her work helping disadvantaged youths stay on the straight and narrow, and this place has a real affirming neighbourhood aura about it.

Full of natural light, greenery and colourful geometric designs, it's made for an afternoon chill. But what really caught us by surprise was how excellent the food was - the jerk chicken with rice, peas and 'slaw was frickin' dope. The perfect level of spice and the perfect level of price, at just £6 for a big old plate. If you live around these ends, make this place your home from home.

text.text: In the Bernie Grant Arts Centre you'll find a colourful neighbourhood spot to warm the heart and the belly. Set up by Gina, who has won awards for helping disadvantaged youths, locals from all walks chill amidst the natural light, greenery and vibrant geometric decor. But don't come here without getting full - the jerk chicken with rice, peas and 'slaw is frickin' dope. The perfect level of spice and the perfect level of price, at just £6 for a big ol' plate.
Best for... a true community boozer

tip.text:
It always warms our cold, hard hearts to hear a pub being saved from developer destruction by the community, and Antwerp Arms is the product of one such feel-good tale. In 2013, 360 locals got together to fight the good fight, and it's been going from strength to strength ever since - the beating heart of this part of town.

Overlooking the green Bruce Castle Park, this Georgian pub has been serving the people the hoppy stuff since 1822 and is Tottenham's oldest established pub. Community really is key here - alongside numerous events (music, karaoke and quiz nights), they also serve unprivileged and homeless people a free lunch every couple of weeks. It also gets live-o before Spurs games.

text.text: Heart-warming tales are a bit of a theme in Tottenham and here's another - a Georgian pub dating all the way back to 1822, saved from developer destruction in 2013 by 360 locals. It's the beating heart of the area, hosting music, karaoke and quiz nights whilst also serving underprivileged and homeless people a hot meal every two weeks. It also gets live-o when Spurs are playing.
Best for... working up a sweat

tip.text:
The speedy evolution of Tottenham continues apace here with a bouldering and yoga studio set up in an old warehouse. Oh, you're not excited? How about if we tell you it's London's largest bouldering centre! That sure got your attention, eh?

Here you'll find hundreds of bouldering problems but also plenty of places to hang about and socialise in and talk about whatever is on your mind - we suggest bouldering related topics to avoid looking like a fraud. There's also a yoga studio, a fully equipped changing room and a nicely stocked café.

text.text: Maybe another bouldering and yoga space doesn't excite you that much... until we tell you that this is London's biggest bouldering centre! Here you'll find hundreds of bouldering problems but also plenty of places to hang about in and talk about whatever is on your mind - we suggest bouldering related topics to avoid looking like a fraud.
Best for... healthy living

tip.text:
Tri Prana is the kind of healthy and holistic nook that you can almost hear your mind and body thanking you for visiting the moment you walk in. During the day it's a calming and sleepy cafe that fills with natural light, making stuff like delicious vegan smoothies, toasted sandwiches, buddha salad bowls and rotis with vegetarian curries. In the evening, it turns into a yoga spot.

Note: This baby tends to be open/closed on weird days so check in before turning up.

text.text: Tri Prana is the type of healthy and holistic nook that you can almost hear your body thanking you for visiting the moment you walk in. During the day it's a sleepy cafe that serves up decent and affordable vegan smoothies, toasted sandwiches, buddha salad bowls and rotis with vegetarian curries. In the evening, it turns into a yoga space. Correct us if we're wrong, but that's the wellness dream if ever we saw it.
Best for... going wild

tip.text: Oh you must have heard about Styx. It's only one of North London's liveliest spots: a big warehouse and yard space that shape shifts to host gigs, weird and wonderful performances and the kind of summer day parties that'll have you feeling everything's alright. Taking advantage of a late licence, this place can really kick off come weekend evenings, whilst there's also a very nice outdoor area with a water feature/pond thing.

text.text: Here we have a real shape-shifter: a raucous venue capable of hosting gigs, summer day parties and weird and wonderful productions. You never really know what you'll get here and we're into it. Taking advantage of a late licence, this place really kicks off come weekend evenings, and there's also a very nice outdoor area with a water feature/pond thing/thermal bath depending on how you see the world.
Best for... friendly pints

tip.text: Everything about this rough-and-ready boozer has us getting a little misty eyed, harking back to a time we're legally obliged to call 'the good old days'. A big block of a building with worn green and yellow paint on the outside, Mannions Prince Arthur is an Irish pub from a time when the Irish lived pretty large in Tottenham, and it's a friendly, no-frills place to sink a pint and have a chat with the locals. It comes with standard stuff on tap, football on the TV and karaoke on Fridays. The decor could certainly do with an update but that only seems to add to the charm of the place.

text.text: Everything about this rough-and-ready boozer has us getting a little misty eyed, harking back to a time we're legally obliged to call 'the good old days'. A big block of a building with distinctive green and yellow paint on the outside, Mannions Prince Arthur is an Irish pub from a time when the Irish lived large in Tottenham. It's a very friendly, no-frills joint - the kind of place where the slightly dated decor only adds to its charm.
Best for... bargain sweet treats

tip.text:
After arriving in the UK in the 80s, John and Emilia Mensah were soon longing for some of that soft-to-the-touch Ghanian sweet bread that's so damn popular back home. After some considerable hustle, they're now the number one Ghanaian Sweet Bread company in the UK, and this is their vibrant HQ - a one stop place to grab sweet breads, donuts and cakes.

Using the archetypal secret family recipe, the results are subtly flavoured baked goods that are expertly spiced without being too sweet or sickly; treats to be enjoyed with a cup of something hot. Stop by here to lay your hands on their savoury pies, cocoa bread or doughnuts - and then tell everyone you know about what a bargain it all is.

text.text: After some considerable hustle, John and Emilia Mensah's Ghanaian sweet bread empire is booming and this is their busy HQ. Using the secret family recipe, the results are subtly flavoured baked goods that are expertly spiced without being too sweet or sickly. Stop by to lay your hands on savoury pies, soft-to-the-touch breads or doughnuts - and then tell everyone you know about what a bargain it was.
Best for... walks on the wild side

tip.text:
Y’know what Londoners can never get enough of? Big ol’ soggy wetlands. After 150 years of secrecy, Walthamstow Wetlands is opening its big gates to the wider public, inviting everyone down for some wholesome fun. Just a 15min hop, jump and skip from central London, find a wildlife oasis perf for some bird watching, angling or just causal strolling amongst Mother Nature. They've also got a weekly calendar of events that changes on the regs, but you can expect the likes of educational trials, home-building workshops and arts & crafts.

Entry to the grounds is free.

text.text: It might be called Walthamstow but it's very close to Tottenham so we're having it. This is a tranquil wildlife oasis ideal for a little bird watching, angling or just casual strolling. The green and blue landscapes are occasionally interrupted by electricity pylons and views of industrial warehouses, but this is Tottenham, where urban grit is all part of the package.
